Award.AwardTitle: Effects of Nickel Content, Inclusion Type and Heat Treatment on the Microstructures and Strength and Toughness of New, Cobalt Free, Ultra-high Strength Steels of High Toughness

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently available ultra-high strength steels of high fracture toughness contain large amounts of cobalt and nickel. Because of these large amounts of cobalt and nickel these steels are relatively expensive. The ultimate objective of this research is the further development of new ultra-high strength steels of high fracture toughness, which contain no cobalt and much less nickel than currently available ultra-high strength steels of high fracture toughness. Explicitly the work will provide a basic understanding as to the effects of composition and heat treatment on the strength and toughness of the new steels. This basic understanding will facilitate the eventual commercial development of a new class of ultra-high strength steels of high fracture toughness, which are much less expensive than currently available ultra-high strength steels of high fracture toughness. Based on the initial results obtained in this work there has been interest in the new steels from steel producers and users of such steels and thus it is felt that the new steels have the potential to be of lasting technological and engineering significance. As the new steel contains no cobalt, which must be imported, the new steels also have benefits in terms of sustainability and national security. This work will contribute to the scientific/engineering training of a woman graduate student who will be supported by the project, and several undergraduates during the school year and summers through the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates supplemental grants.

The new steels are medium carbon secondary hardening steels in which nickel additions, rather than cobalt, are used to enhance strengthening by secondary hardening, which is the strengthening by the precipitation of fine alloy carbides. Nickel is used instead of cobalt because nickel is less expensive than cobalt and because nickel lowers the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature while cobalt raises the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature. Both the strength and toughness of the new steels are strongly influenced by the amount of nickel added to the steel. Thus a major objective of the proposed work is to understand how nickel additions influence the microstructure and hence the strength and toughness of the new steels. The second objective of the proposed work is to examine the effects of inclusion type on the toughness of the new steels. Inclusions in steels are second phase particles used to remove from solid solution certain impurities such as sulfur. The inclusion type can influence the toughness when the fracture mode is ductile and can also influence the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature. Our specific interest in this work is to assess the effects of inclusion type on the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature of the new steels.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this work was to develop a new ultra-high strength steel of high fracture toughness which would be less expensive than currently available high toughness ultra-high strength steels. High toughness ultra-high strength steels which are presently available contain large amounts of cobalt and nickel. The new steels developed here contain no cobalt and much reduced levels of nickel.

The approach taken to the development of these neew steels was essentially to modify a medium carbon secondary hardening steel similar to H-11 or H-13. These steels contain one wt. % silicon and silicon is used as it enhances  secondary hardening. But silicon also reduces the toughness. So our approach was to not use silicon additions but instead additions of nickel. An addition of 4 wt. % nickel will enhance secondary to about the same degree as 1 wt. % silicon. The nickel additions enhance secondary hardening and they also improve the toughness.

In this work we considered additions of nickel to a base secondary hardening steel having a composition, in wt. %, of 0.38C-4.5Cr-2Mo-0.5W-0.5V. The nickel additions considered were 3, 5 and 6 wt. %. In this work we examined the effects of austenitizing temperature, of the rate of cooling from the austenitizing temperature, tempering temperature and single versus triple tempers. The austenitizing temperatures considered were 1050°C, 1025°C and 1000°C. Austenitizing at 1025°C results in a slightly lower yield strength than austenitizing at 1050°C, but there is a significant increase in Charpy toughness. Austentizing at 1000°C results in a significantly reduced yield sttength. We found that always an air cool resulted in a higher strength but a lower toughness than an oil quench from the austenitizing temperature. We examined tempering temperatures of 525°C, 550°C and 575°C. The strength after tempering at 575°C was low. Tempering at 550°C resulted in a higher yield strength and a lower ultimate tensile strength than tempering at 525°C.

We carried out a study of the effect of heat treatment on the Charpy impact energy for the compositions considered above and also for a number of compositions in which the chromium and molybdenum were varied in a systematic way but which contained no nickel. We considered austenitizing at 1000°C and 1050°C and for each temperature we considered an air cool and an oil quench. We always tempered at 550°C. What we found was that all compositions had an excellent Charpy energy on oil quenching from 1000°C, there was no effect of chromium content or of nickel content. But whe we air cooled from 1050°C we found that all of the heats which contained no nickel had very low Charpy energies. So nickel is essential to achieving good toughness in these steels given realistic heat treatments.

Considering the austenitizing temperature of 1050°C and air cooling from the austenitizing we found that the heats with no nickel had ductile-to-brittle transition temperatures (DBTT) of 100°C or higher. When 3 wt. % nickel was added to the steels the DBTT was reduced to -40°C. When 5 and 6 wt. % nickel were added the DBTT were reduced to less than -80°C. While we expect nickel in solid solution to lower the DBTT we expect the DBTT to be reduced by only about 17°C per wt. % nickel. There is no way that nickel in solid solution can lower the DBTT to the levels observed for the different nickel levels. Thus nickel must be doing something to change the microstructure in such a way as to lower the DBTT.

Another important consideration in using these steels is that they are very prone to quench cracking because of thier high chromium levels as the volume expansion associated with the austenitie to martensite phase change increase with chromium content. So that oil quenching these steels is not really possible. 

These steels were awarded a patent on June 7, 2016. The title of the patent is "HIgh Toughness Secondary Hardening Steel". The patent number is 9,359,653.


Last Modified: 09/04/2017
Modified by: Warren M Garrison
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this work was to develop a new ultra-high strength steel of high fracture toughness which would be less expensive than currently available high toughness ultra-high strength steels. High toughness ultra-high strength steels which are presently available contain large amounts of cobalt and nickel. The new steels developed here contain no cobalt and much reduced levels of nickel. The approach taken to the development of these neew steels was essentially to modify a medium carbon secondary hardening steel similar to H-11 or H-13. These steels contain one wt. % silicon and silicon is used as it enhances secondary hardening. But silicon also reduces the toughness. So our approach was to not use silicon additions but instead additions of nickel. An addition of 4 wt. % nickel will enhance secondary to about the same degree as 1 wt. % silicon. The nickel additions enhance secondary hardening and they also improve the toughness. In this work we considered additions of nickel to a base secondary hardening steel having a composition, in wt. %, of 0.38C-4.5Cr-2Mo-0.5W-0.5V. The nickel additions considered were 3, 5 and 6 wt. %. In this work we examined the effects of austenitizing temperature, of the rate of cooling from the austenitizing temperature, tempering temperature and single versus triple tempers. The austenitizing temperatures considered were 1050°C, 1025°C and 1000°C. Austenitizing at 1025°C results in a slightly lower yield strength than austenitizing at 1050°C, but there is a significant increase in Charpy toughness. Austentizing at 1000°C results in a significantly reduced yield sttength. We found that always an air cool resulted in a higher strength but a lower toughness than an oil quench from the austenitizing temperature. We examined tempering temperatures of 525°C, 550°C and 575°C. The strength after tempering at 575°C was low. Tempering at 550°C resulted in a higher yield strength and a lower ultimate tensile strength than tempering at 525°C. We carried out a study of the effect of heat treatment on the Charpy impact energy for the compositions considered above and also for a number of compositions in which the chromium and molybdenum were varied in a systematic way but which contained no nickel. We considered austenitizing at 1000°C and 1050°C and for each temperature we considered an air cool and an oil quench. We always tempered at 550°C. What we found was that all compositions had an excellent Charpy energy on oil quenching from 1000°C, there was no effect of chromium content or of nickel content. But whe we air cooled from 1050°C we found that all of the heats which contained no nickel had very low Charpy energies. Considering the austenitizing temperature of 1050°C and air cooling from the austenitizing we found that the heats with no nickel had ductile-to-brittle transition temperatures (DBTT) of 100°C or higher. There is no way that nickel in solid solution can lower the DBTT to the levels observed for the different nickel levels. Thus nickel must be doing something to change the microstructure in such a way as to lower the DBTT. Another important consideration in using these steels is that they are very prone to quench cracking because of thier high chromium levels as the volume expansion associated with the austenitie to martensite phase change increase with chromium content. So that oil quenching these steels is not really possible. These steels were awarded a patent on June 7, 2016. The title of the patent is "HIgh Toughness Secondary Hardening Steel". The patent number is 9,359,653. Last Modified: 09/04/2017 Submitted by: Warren M Garrison
